Hovey — 4
Working at odd jobs all the while, young Pella completed the work
for his diploma in accounting at 18 and took his degree in economics
and commerce from the University of Turin at 22.
Then he took a teaching job in a technical school at Biella, but
simultaneously launched an independent professional career as a business
consultant*
What happened immediately after that really is straight out of
Horatio Alger. A few years after taking his university degree, Pella
was consultant to the most substantial Industries in his home city of
Biella* Before he was 30 he had as clients the main textile industries
of north Italy.
It has been said that from about 1930 until the outbreak of World
War II there was no important European conference of woolen manufacturers
which Pella did not attend.
While establishing himself in business, Pella apparently put aside
an Interest in politics he had developed as a university student* He
served one term as vice-mayor of Biella in the mid-1930s, which indicates
that at that point he was not openly and mllitantly anti-Fasclst* But
friends say he did this out of civic duty to straighten out the communed
finances.
The Catholic bishop of Biella generally gets the credit for per¬
suading Pella to get into politics under the banner of the Christian
Democratic party after the war* Pella got the most votes in a Biella
city election in March, 1946, and was elected to the Italian constituent
assembly that June*
